description.narrative: The Somalia Joint Justice Programme (JJP) supports the NDP 2017-2019 goal to ‘Establish independent, accountable and efficient justice institutions capable of addressing the justice needs of the people of Somalia’.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: # of CSOs members trained on communication conversation with increase in knowledge ; # local justice and security plans developed; SOP # of justice and police stakeholder’s coordination meetings; # of public fora on justice and security and # people reached # legal messages developed for distribution # people receiving legal aid services (M/F/IDP status); # number of legal aid centres and # cases handled (M/F); # victims treated and # cases referred to formal justice system # mobile courts active; # districts that have mobile courts and # cases addressed by mobile courts amount of court fees collected /month per location as recorded by court fees management board # of evaluations conducted # of project monitoring visits per quarter 1 0# of PSC’s held during programme implementation # of Annual GFP’s Retreat

comment.narrative: - No coordination and/or technical committee mechanism exists - Political agreement on JCM but not endorsed by the NSC; jurisdictions, roles and responsibilities and relationships not discussed in details yet - No FMS and Federal justice state plans exist; 0 progress report on implementation of the plans - No JSC exists - No information desk established across Somalia. - Draft advocates act developed - however, only one Bar Association currently exists in Puntland - No legal aid boards established and functional - System set up in Banadir and Puntland - Informal trainings of 10 instructors and 10 modules developed without a formal training architecture in place -184 judges, prosecutors and registrars trained under ROL - SGBV units established in PL and Mogadishu - No SOPs developed and adopted on AGO and Police on processing of criminal cases by type of cases (SGBV, juveniles) - Annual colloquium for prosecutors in 2017 - 5 interns at the AGO in Mogadishu - 147 (W:48, M:99) benefit from the scholarship programme - Mechanism to record exists - Draft advocates act developed - however, only one Bar Association currently exists in Puntland - 0 legal aid boards established and functional - 21 laws, 3 policies and 2 concept notes produced by PLDU in the last ROL document period (2014-2017). - No published resources available to the public on laws of Somalia - 0 CSOs members trained on communication conversation with increase in knowledge ; 0 local justice and security plans developed; SOP - 0 justice and police stakeholder’s coordination meetings, no public fora on justice and security exists - Total 26,411 (W: 19,515; M: 6,896) people reached through various means including through MC - 24,633 (W: 17,953, M: 6,680) people received legal aid; 6 legal aid centers; 19 paralegals (W: 15, M: 4) - 2,427 (W: 1,812, M:615) supported by CDR centers in Puntland 22,391 legal aid in 2017 - 277 (Criminal: 107; Civil: 170) cases addressed by MC - 0 amount of court f

1.1 50 decisions derived from consensus within the community 1,800 people disaggregated by gender, age and vulnerability, actively involved in community conversation sessions
1.2 10,000 beneficiaries disaggregated by gender, age and vulnerability, receiving legal aid services 1,500 beneficiaries disaggregated by gender, age and vulnerability, receiving services from the ADR centres 500 beneficiaries disaggregated by gender, age and vulnerability, receiving services through mobile courts 2 pilot projects based on community-based response to SGBV and juvenile cases developed through the community dispute resolution centre and implemented in two locations in Baidoa and Kismayo Strategy on providing justice to recovered areas developed and implemented in one location
2.1 2 FMS Rule of Law Working Groups
2.2 Ongoing support for SGBV units in PL and Mogadishu 180 law students benefitting from the programme

1.1 Community Conversations still ongoing and decisions yet to be quantified. A total of 3,200 people (F:1,739, M:1,461) participated in the community conversation sessions.
1.2 2,671 beneficiaries receiving legal representation or paralegal services (F:1,710, M:961 IDPs: no reliable data) 2,458 beneficiaries receiving services from the ADR Centres (F: 1,092, M:1,366) 403 beneficiaries receiving services through the mobile courts (F: 186, M:217) No progress
2.1 1 ROL Strand 2C WG meeting took place on 23 March 2021
2.2 24 SGBV cases were handled by the AGO SGBV Unit in Mogadishu. 51 SGBV cases were handled by the AGO SGBV Unit in Puntland. 236 (F:80, M:156) students benefitted from the legal scholarship programme during the reporting period, continuing from previous scholarship awards. No new scholarships were awarded during the reporting period.

1. Set of decisions related to justice and security agreed upon consensus by the community including specific decisions on SGBV/women’s access to justice 2. Community Conversations Participants 3. 8000 (50% women, and 50% IDPs) beneficiaries of legal aid 4. 2000 beneficiaries received ADR services 5. 500 mobile court cases addressed 6. Project concept developed based on emerging practices 7. Research action about justice needs in recovered areas (including transitional justice) with plan developed 8. Rule of law working group established and operationalized; bi-monthly meeting 9. Basic principles on federalism on the justice sector emerges from the discussions 10. Workplan for the PER 11. 2 information desks established as pilot in 3 institutions 12. Courts in 2 FMS capitals 13. Policy framework for judicial training agreed 14. Specialised GBV and serious crimes unit established at AGO FGS 15. 332 juveniles diverted 16. 30% of legal scholarship students are female 17. Roadmap and strategy for transfer of high-risk cases to the civilian court, agreed upon 18. 2 bar associations established; 30 lawyers trained 19. 5 laws monitored 20. 1 mid-term evaluation undertaken 21. 4 PSCs 22. 1 annual UN Global Focal Point arrangements for Rule of Law’s retreat

As of June 2020: 1. Community facilitators have started to conduct community conversations at sites in all locations focusing on the first stages of the community conversations process: building trust and identifying concerns. Initial response to the community conversations have been positive, with interest from local communities to participate. 2. A total of 1604 people (F: 893, M: 711) have participated in the community conversations thus far. 3. 4,407 beneficiaries receiving legal representation or paralegal services (F: 2,904, M: 1,503, IDPs: 2,128) 4. 1,330 beneficiaries receiving services from the ADR centres (F: 599, M: 731) 5. 178 beneficiaries receiving services through the mobile courts (F: 61, M: 117) 6. Convergence between community based social norms change programmes and Alternative Dispute Resolution mechanisms have been initiated in 2020. The implementation of these pilot projects had to be postponed due to COVID 19. 7. Concept note for bringing justice to the recovered areas developed and shared with the strategic partners and donors. 8. Concept of Rule of Law Working Group revised with support from donors and UN to ensure stronger delivery on coordination and strategic planning 9. The consultations on the Justice and Corrections model have been integrated in the constitutional review process. 10. Concept note on financial analysis of the justice sector developed and awaiting comments from RoL Working Group 11. Information desks established and operational for Banadir Regional Court, Banadir Appeal Court, and the Supreme Court. Guides for court users have been developed and finalized. 12. The case management system in Benadir was revamped to improve case flow and access to information by relevant court officials. 13. Technical and advisory support have continued to be provided to the Office of the Chief Justice to leverage the learnings from the JTI Options Paper, Strategic Framework/Roadmap. The stakeholder consultation planned to support the adoption of the JTI draft charter and the initiation of institutional structures for the JTI have been postponed until Q3 2020. Plans made for the next phase of Judicial Training have also been postponed due to COVID-19, with contingencies being explored for conducting some trainings of trainers online in Q3/4. In the meantime, the international expert on judicial training has developed further training material which has been submitted to the Supreme Court for approval. 14. 109 SGBV cases (F: 109; M: 0) handled by AGOs in Mogadishu and Puntland. 2 embedded advisors (SGBV Legal Advisor and AGO Technical Coordinator), and three interns. A training manual for Somali prosecutors on prosecutorial trial advocacy, particularly on SGBV cases, is in the process of being developed. 15. In Puntland, diversion guidelines drafted in 2019 are being implemented. 234 children (F:38, M:196) were released during the reporting period. At the Federal level, 206 children (F:13, M:193) were diverted in Benadir. 16. A total of 173 students currently benefit from the legal scholarship programme (F: 64, M: 109). 110 students (F: 40, M: 70) received the legal scholarship to study at Mogadishu University. 63 students (F: 24, M: 39) received the legal scholarship to study at Puntland State University. 51 law graduate interns (F: 17, M: 34) have undertaken internship programmes at various units of the judiciary, including the Office of the Supreme Court, Ministries of Justice and District Courts at both FGS and FMS. 17. N/A 18. Three embedded staff have been retained, and two embedded staff and two interns have additionally been recruited, to ensure the secretariat’s continued functioning. A Trial Advocacy Manual is being developed for the training of lawyers and designing trainings for Somali lawyers and legal graduates. Capacity building initiatives have focused on practical courtroom skills. 19. 12 laws, policies, legislations drafted/reviewed in 2020. 20. The consultant hired to conduct the mid-term evaluation has completed the evaluation and submitted the final report. The programme team has reviewed the report and is in the process of finalizing management responses to the recommendations provided. 21. 2 PSCs held 22. 1-day meeting

1.Target: Technical committees and state plans developed and established in each FMS
2. Target: Basic case management system at courts established in each FMS
3. Target: Harmonized judiciary training curriculum developed
4. Target: 100 judges, prosecutors and registrars trained on the harmonized judiciary training curriculum
5. Target: To support graduate students at each FMS and FGS
6. Target: Scholarships provided to students from each FGS
7. Target: Laws and polices reviewed and developed by PLDU FGS and MoJs in FMS
8 Target: Community conversations conducted in Jubaland, South-West State and Benadir
9. Target: Legal aid services established and provided in each FMS
10. Target: 10 ADR centers across all FMS and Benadir providing services
11. Target: Mobile courts addressing cases in all FMS

Results for Q1 2019
1. Results: Technical committee and state plan developed and established in Puntland
2. Results: Standardized case file format procedure agreed and action plan for harmonized case file procedure developed in Galmudug
3. Results: Draft curriculum developed and submitted to relevant ministries for consultation
4. Nothing to report
5. Results: 54 graduate students from all FMS and FGS supported as interns
6. Results: 85 students from Benadir, Jubaland, Hirshabelle, South-West State and Galmudug supported with scholarships
7. Results: 6 Bills and 1 report have been amended, reviewed and corrected by referring to other related national/international laws by the relevant ministries and 2 policies have been translated into Somali, reviewed and amended and after that shared with concerned Unit in the Ministry for implementation.
8. Result: Lead consultant identified and recruited
9. Results: 220 clients mediated with support of lawyers and paralegal assistance outside the court in Puntland
10. Result: Cases registered in 16 ADR centres: 793 cases (M:561; F:232) in all FMS
11. Result: 126 cases (106 civilian; 20 criminal) addressed by mobile courts in Hirshabelle, Puntland, Galmudug, South-West State and Jubaland
